intro: Benzingia jarae, commonly known as the Jarae sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the arid regions of northern South America. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes grass-like plants known for their ecological importance in wetland and dryland ecosystems. The plant typically grows in dense clumps with narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikelets. It is well adapted to harsh environments, exhibiting drought tolerance and efficient water use. Its botanical characteristics make it an important component of its native habitats, supporting local biodiversity.
